title: 115_hr3629
content: The "Payroll Fraud Prevention Act of 2017" is the short title of this Act. It includes provisions for the classification of employees and non-employees. The "Payroll Fraud Prevention Act of 2017" includes definitions for non-employees and covered individuals, distinguishing between employees and non-employees engaged for labor or services. The "Payroll Fraud Prevention Act of 2017" defines individuals required to file an information return under section 6041A(a) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, including those providing labor or services through entities like trusts, estates, partnerships, associations, companies, or corporations. This applies if the individual has an ownership interest in the entity, the entity's creation or maintenance is a condition for providing labor or services, and the person would need to file an information return for the entity under section 6041A(a) of the Internal Revenue Code. The "Payroll Fraud Prevention Act of 2017" expands the classification of employees under the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 to include individuals required to file an information return under section 6041A(a) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This applies to entities like trusts, estates, partnerships, associations, companies, or corporations if the individual has an ownership interest in the entity and the entity's creation or maintenance is a condition for providing labor or services. The "Payroll Fraud Prevention Act of 2017" expands employee classification under the Fair Labor Standards Act to include individuals required to file an information return. Employers must accurately classify individuals as employees or non-employees and provide a notice to each individual. The Payroll Fraud Prevention Act of 2017 requires employers to provide a notice to each covered individual within 6 months of enactment, and thereafter upon employment for new employees and commencement of services for new non-employees. Additionally, individuals must be notified of any change in their status as an employee or non-employee. The notice required under the Payroll Fraud Prevention Act of 2017 must inform individuals of their classification as an employee or non-employee, direct them to the Department of Labor website for more information on legal rights, and provide contact information for the local office. The Payroll Fraud Prevention Act of 2017 requires notices to inform individuals of their proper classification as an employee or non-employee, provide contact information for the Department of Labor, and include a statement about labor protections and classification rights. The Payroll Fraud Prevention Act of 2017 mandates that a covered individual must be presumed as an employee if not provided with proper notice within the specified time. The presumption can only be refuted with clear and convincing evidence. Amendments are made to the Fair Labor Standards Act regarding special prohibited acts. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 is amended to prohibit discrimination against covered individuals who oppose any practice related to the Act or file complaints. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 is amended to include penalties for misclassifying employees and violating recordkeeping and notice requirements. This includes wrongly classifying an employee as a non-employee and imposes special penalties for such violations. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 is amended to include penalties for misclassifying employees and violating recordkeeping and notice requirements, imposing special penalties for wrongly classifying an employee as a non-employee. Amendments include changing terminology from "employee" to "covered individual" and specifying consent requirements for covered individuals. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 is amended to include penalties for misclassifying employees and violating recordkeeping and notice requirements. Penalties are imposed for wrongly classifying an employee as a non-employee, with changes in terminology to "covered individual" and specifying consent requirements. Liquidated damages are doubled for violations of specific sections, including section 15(a)(6). Any person who violates specific sections of the Fair Labor Standards Act shall be subject to civil penalties, ranging from $1,100 to $5,000 per individual affected by the violation. The Secretary of Labor will create a webpage summarizing employee rights under the Fair Labor Standards Act within 180 days of the Act's enactment. Additionally, there will be measures to address the misclassification of employees for unemployment compensation purposes. The Social Security Act is amended to include auditing procedures to identify non-compliant employers and unreported wages, with quarterly reports to the Secretary of Labor. The amendment includes procedures for auditing to detect non-compliant employers and unreported wages for unemployment compensation purposes, along with the establishment of penalties for misclassification of employees. The Secretary of Labor will assess States' performance in identifying underreported wages and unemployment contributions, even in the absence of proper documentation. The amendments made by subsection (a) of the Act will take effect 12 months after enactment, unless a State requires legislation to comply, in which case the amendments will apply later of the close of the first regular session of the State legislature or 12 months after enactment. The term "State" is defined as per section 3306(j) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. SEC. 5. DEPARTMENT OF LABOR COORDINATION, REFERRAL, AND REGULATIONS. (a) Any office, administration, or division of the Department of Labor obtaining information on misclassification under the Fair Labor Standards Act must report it to the Wage and Hour Division. The Division may further report to the Internal Revenue Service. (b) The Secretary of Labor will issue regulations. The Secretary of Labor will issue regulations to implement this Act and its amendments. SEC. 6. TARGETED AUDITS. Audits of employers under the Fair Labor Standards Act will focus on industries prone to misclassifying employees as non-employees, as determined by the Secretary of Labor.
